column1: Imagine you are indoors on a sunny day. A beam of sunlight through a window lights up a section of the floor. How would you draw this sunbeam? You might draw a series of parallel lines showing the path of the sunlight from the window to the floor. This is not exactly accurate — no matter how hard you look
column2: you will not find unique lines of light in the sunbeam! However
column3: this is a good way to draw light and to model light geometrically.We call these narrow
column4: imaginary lines of light light rays. Recall that light can behave like a wave and so you can think of a light ray as the path of a point on the crest of a wave.We can use light rays to model the behaviour of light relative to mirrors
column8: and prisms. The study of how light interacts with materials is called optics.When dealing with light rays
column9: we are usually interested in the shape of a material and the angles at which light rays hit it.
